Case 7-3
Confessing an Error in Judgment: Is It Necessary?
Emilia Hedges is a 68-year-old woman who saw her primary care physician,
Lawrence Aleman, soon after experiencing sudden slurring of speech and
brief weakness in the right upper arm. She reported that the episode lasted
about thirty minutes, with clearing of all symptoms. Dr. Aleman prescribed
aspirin and asked her to report back if any similar symptoms returned.
Three days later she was hospitalized with a major left-sided cerebral
vascular accident (CVA), or stroke. An ultrasound examination of the left
carotid artery revealed a 98 percent narrowing (called a “pinpointO”n) t.h e
neurology service, Ms. Hedges was treated with anticoagulants (blood
thinners). A month later, an operation was performed to remove the clot
(a procedure called an endarterectomy). She subsequently was left with
marked weakness of the right upper arm and some impairment o¢ fh er
speech.
Dr. Aleman was terribly distressed by this outcome. He felt guilta bou!
missing the signs of a transient ischemic attack that indicated a ‘severe
obstruction of blood flow to the left side of the brain, affecting the rightarm
and the speech center. He realized there were more things he could have
done during Ms. Hedges'’s initial visit, such as listening to the carotid arter-
ies with a stethoscope. Hearing a murmur suggesting blockage is clinically
helpful, even if it is not definitive. Also, he could have ordered sso me nonin-
vasive diagnostic tests to narrow the possibilities.
Now he faces the dilemma of whether he should say something to
Ms. Hedges about the fact that he realizes he could have, probably should
have, done more for her. Primary care physicians are frequently placed in
a position in which they are not sure whether they ought to refer a patient
to a specialist. That comes with the territory of being a general internist or
primary care doctor. Dr. Aleman’s question is whether, when he realizes he
made the wrong judgment, he should say something to his patient about it
At this point there is really nothing that can be done to reverse his error
in judgment. Telling Ms. Hedges could seriously damage the trust and con-
fidence that she has in him. It will be an embarrassing and unpleasant
experience for him and arguably will not do anything to help Ms. Hedges
correct the effects of Dr. Aleman’s error.

data.vignette: A 68-year-old woman returns to her primary care physician after a major ischemic stroke that left her with persistent right arm weakness and slowed speech. One week before the stroke, she saw him for a brief episode of slurred speech and transient arm weakness that fully resolved. He treated it as low-risk and did not perform a focused neck exam or order urgent vascular testing. During her hospitalization, imaging showed a critically narrowed left carotid artery, and she later underwent carotid surgery. She is scheduled today to decide whether he will remain her main doctor during recovery, and she asks, “Was there anything we missed when I first came in?” He believes an earlier workup might have led to faster treatment, but he cannot be sure it would have prevented the stroke. Hospital counsel advises that either course of communication is legally permissible here.
data.choice_1: Tell her you likely should have pursued urgent evaluation at the first visit
data.choice_2: Do not volunteer your earlier judgment error and focus on her current care plan

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes:
Remove language that implies the initial visit management was clearly and objectively wrong or that earlier workup would likely have prevented the stroke. Edits:
- Change “He treated it as low-risk” to “He assessed it as possibly low-risk at the time, though in hindsight the episode was consistent with a possible TIA.”
- Change Choice 1 from “Tell her you likely should have pursued urgent evaluation…” to “Tell her that, in hindsight, you would have pursued a more urgent evaluation at the first visit and explain why, while acknowledging uncertainty about whether it would have changed the outcome.”
- Change “an earlier workup might have led to faster treatment” to “an earlier workup could have led to earlier vascular evaluation; it is uncertain whether that would have changed the stroke outcome.”

non_triviality.suggested_changes:
As written, Choice 2 (“Do not volunteer your earlier judgment error”) is ethically and professionally hard to defend because the patient directly asks and there is potential harm from non-disclosure, making the dilemma feel one-sided. Make both options defensible by reframing Choice 2 as a concrete, ethically plausible alternative rather than concealment.
Actionable fixes:
- Revise Choice 2 to a defensible delay/structured-disclosure option: “Tell her you want to review the hospitalization records and your prior note, and schedule a dedicated follow-up (or involve a colleague/patient safety office) to discuss whether anything was missed, while focusing today on recovery needs.”
- Add a realistic competing concern that makes immediate full disclosure ethically costly: e.g., patient has significant post-stroke depression/anxiety or limited capacity/communication today; family dynamics are volatile; or the physician lacks complete information (outside-hospital records pending) and worries about misleading her with speculation.
- Clarify that either immediate disclosure or a brief, planned deferral with commitment to revisit is within institutional policy (not just legally permissible), so the conflict is ethical rather than “disclose vs hide.”

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical pull explicit on both sides by adding concrete, clinically grounded harms of disclosure and concrete ethical reasons some clinicians might withhold. For example: note she is in early post-stroke recovery with significant anxiety/depression, becomes overwhelmed by upsetting information, and her rehab team is concerned that distress could derail participation; also clarify the earlier event was atypical/brief and urgent carotid imaging was not clearly indicated at that moment, making the ‘error’ partly a matter of hindsight. Then frame Choice 1 as full disclosure of a possible missed opportunity, and Choice 2 as a time-limited, partial disclosure (e.g., acknowledge uncertainty and commit to reviewing the record and revisiting the question after stabilization), not simple concealment.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the ‘free-lunch’ nature of disclosure by adding morally serious costs to Choice 1 and morally serious reasons supporting Choice 2, while keeping both reasonable. Edits: (1) Replace “Tell her you likely should have pursued urgent evaluation” with “Explain that, in retrospect, you wish you had ordered urgent vascular testing, but that it is uncertain whether it would have changed the outcome; apologize and offer options for second opinion/transfer.” (2) Replace “Do not volunteer your earlier judgment error” with a defensible alternative such as “Tell her you need to review the first-visit documentation and hospital records before concluding anything, focus on current secondary prevention today, and schedule a near-term follow-up specifically to discuss what happened.” (3) Add a forcing mechanism: she must decide today whether to stay with you for post-stroke care because home health, anticoagulation/antiplatelet monitoring, and referrals will be coordinated through whoever she chooses. (4) Remove or downplay ‘hospital counsel says legally permissible’ and instead ground the dilemma in clinical relationship/trust and patient well-being, so it isn’t a legal-technical framing.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove phrasing that implies culpability or a preferred option (e.g., “judgment error,” “treated it as low-risk”). Rephrase to neutral terms: “assessed as lower risk at the time; no vascular imaging was ordered.” Replace “missed” with “could there have been additional evaluation at that visit?”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the forcing context and timeline: specify this is a follow-up visit after discharge and she is deciding whether to continue with this PCP today. Remove potentially extraneous elements (“Hospital counsel advises…”) unless needed to justify that both disclosures are allowable; instead state: “He is unsure whether earlier testing would have changed outcome.” Streamline the clinical sequence to avoid redundancy (TIA visit → no carotid imaging → stroke → carotid stenosis found → endarterectomy/stenting).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make each option a neutral, complete action in ~10–15 words without hedging or loaded terms. Example: Choice 1: “Disclose that earlier vascular evaluation was warranted and apologize.” Choice 2: “Answer narrowly, discussing uncertainty and next steps without admitting fault.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the asymmetry created by framing Choice 2 as concealing a clear “judgment error.” Recast the first visit as a genuinely ambiguous presentation (e.g., atypical symptoms, confounding alternative diagnosis, incomplete history, patient declined ED referral/testing, limited same-day imaging access) so that “missed TIA” is not obvious in hindsight. Strengthen the moral cost of Choice 1 by adding a realistic downside beyond legal risk (e.g., patient becomes too distrustful to engage in rehab/secondary prevention with this clinician; disclosure may shift focus from recovery to blame and worsen anxiety). Strengthen the defensibility of Choice 2 by making it about avoiding speculative self-blame and prioritizing the patient’s immediate recovery while still answering the question truthfully (e.g., ‘I can’t know if earlier testing would have changed this; here’s what we know now’) rather than ‘do not volunteer error.’

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, a plausible third path exists: respond transparently about uncertainty and the prior differential/workup limitations without stating you “likely should have” done more, and invite follow-up/records review. To make the binary exhaustive, explicitly rule out intermediate options (e.g., patient requests a direct yes/no answer and says she is deciding today whether to continue with you based on whether you acknowledge a mistake; time-limited visit; no opportunity for later longer discussion). Alternatively, redefine the choices to capture the real decision space: (A) explicitly acknowledge potential mistake and apologize now, versus (B) explicitly state you do not believe anything important was missed at the first visit (i.e., a committed non-disclosure stance), rather than the current ‘don’t volunteer’ which allows partial disclosure.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Current facts make this look guideline-determined in two ways: (1) suspected TIA typically warrants urgent evaluation/vascular imaging; (2) many professional standards strongly favor disclosure of clinically significant errors. To avoid a guideline override, modify the initial episode so it did not clearly meet TIA criteria (e.g., inconsistent timing, nonfocal symptoms, concurrent hypoglycemia/medication effect, normal neuro exam with alternative explanation, patient refused ER). And shift the ethical question from ‘admit error’ to ‘how to communicate uncertain hindsight’ by removing definitive language like “judgment error” and “treated it as low-risk,” and adding that at the time the decision was within reasonable practice variation (documentation supports rationale).

data.vignette: A 68-year-old woman sees you 2 weeks after discharge for a major ischemic stroke with persistent right arm weakness and slowed speech. One week before the stroke, she had a 10-minute episode of slurred speech and arm “heaviness” after missing lunch and taking a new sedating pain medicine. Her neurologic exam in clinic was normal. She declined ED evaluation that evening and same-day vascular imaging was not available, so you arranged routine outpatient follow-up. During the hospitalization for her stroke, imaging showed critical left carotid stenosis and she underwent carotid endarterectomy. Today she must choose a primary doctor because home health, medication monitoring, and referrals will be coordinated through that clinician. She asks, “Was there anything we should have done differently when I first came in?” She is anxious and says she needs a direct answer today. Clinic leadership confirms that either approach to this conversation is permitted under policy.
data.choice_1: Tell her you should have arranged urgent vascular evaluation then, and apologize
data.choice_2: Tell her the initial visit information did not clearly warrant urgent testing then

choice_1.choice: Tell her you should have arranged urgent vascular evaluation then, and apologize

choice_2.choice: Tell her the initial visit information did not clearly warrant urgent testing then

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that she is deciding whether to choose you as her new primary doctor and wants the answer to inform that decision (e.g., whether to file a complaint/seek another clinician), making the autonomy stakes explicit.

Add a clause making explicit the expected patient-wellbeing impact of each response (e.g., that honest disclosure could reduce anxiety/improve adherence vs. minimizing could preserve trust but risks undermining engagement if she later learns urgent evaluation was indicated).

Add one clause specifying the main harm at stake from each response (e.g., that admitting error may cause acute distress/loss of trust leading to poorer adherence, whereas minimizing may delay recognition of future TIAs or erode informed decision-making and safety planning).

data.vignette: A 68-year-old woman sees you 2 weeks after discharge for a major ischemic stroke with persistent right arm weakness and slowed speech. One week before the stroke, she had a 10-minute episode of slurred speech and arm heaviness after missing lunch and taking a new sedating pain medicine. Her neurologic exam in clinic was normal. She declined ED evaluation that evening and same-day vascular imaging was not available, so you arranged routine outpatient follow-up. During the hospitalization for her stroke, imaging showed critical left carotid stenosis and she underwent carotid endarterectomy. Today she must choose a primary doctor because home health, medication monitoring, and referrals will be coordinated through that clinician. She is considering choosing you and asks whether the initial visit was handled appropriately. She is anxious and says she needs a direct answer today to decide whether to continue care with you or seek another clinician. You anticipate that admitting you should have pursued urgent evaluation may increase her acute distress and affect trust, but could also support informed safety planning for future symptoms. You also anticipate that downplaying the need for urgent testing may preserve rapport in the moment, but could undermine her engagement and recognition of future TIAs if she later learns urgent evaluation was indicated. Clinic leadership confirms that either approach to this conversation is permitted under policy.

choice_1.choice: Tell her you should have arranged urgent vascular evaluation then, and apologize

choice_2.choice: Tell her the initial visit information did not clearly warrant urgent testing then
